question: What is contact tracing?
answer:
Contact tracing is a strategy used to determine the source of an infection and how it is spreading. Finding people who are close contacts to a person who has tested positive for COVID-19, and therefore at higher risk of becoming infected themselves, can help prevent further spread of the virus.
A team of callers tries to reach anyone who has tested positive for COVID-19. They ask the patient questions about their activities within a certain timeframe â to help identify anyone they had close contact with. (Close contact means being closer than six feet apart for a long time while the person was infectious.) Those contacts might include family members, co-workers or health care providers. Please note, the Health Department only uses a live person for contact tracing and never uses anything that sounds like a âroboâ (computer-generated voice) call.
The team then gets in touch with those contacts and provides health guidance on what to do if you are a close contact of someone who is diagnosed with COVID-19. A close contact is asked to stay home for 14 days and watch for symptoms.
While we have been successful in contact tracing, we will continue to add resources and personnel needed to address any increase in the number of people who test positive, which we expect to happen with more testing. This includes the use of technology to help in these efforts. We will be using an app called SARA Alert, a secure monitoring and reporting system for public health that is being used in other states. This system will allow us to offer people who have tested positive for COVID-19, and their close contacts, to enroll in a text-based system to help us keep in touch and monitor their symptoms.
As the state reopens, Vermonters should consider keeping a contact journal â a list of other people who you have been in close contact with each day. If you do get sick, this would make it easier to get in touch with those people and so they can take proper precautions to prevent further spread of COVID-19.

question: What is the Health Department doing about long-term care facilities, nursing homes, assisted living facilities, and senior housing facilities?
answer:
The Heath Department is contacting all long-term care facilities, nursing homes, assisted living facilities, and senior housing facilities proactively to review strategies to prevent COVID-19 infection and develop plans to respond immediately if an infection is identified. We complete an in-depth assessment by phone and provide guidance about personal protective equipment and other infection prevention and control recommendations. We continue to stay in touch for any technical assistance needs and additional questions.
If a case of COVID-19 is associated with a long-term care facility, an epidemiology team is quickly activated. They contact the facility to provide recommendations and infection control support. The team begins contact tracing to determine the source of the infection and how it may be spreading. They ask questions and collect information to help identify anyone the patient had close contact with. (Close contact means being closer than 6 feet apart for a long time while the person was infectious.) The team communicates with close contacts to ensure isolation and quarantine guidelines are being followed, which will differ depending on the type of setting.

question: What should dentists know about COVID-19?
answer:
On April 27, a dental health care referral network for emergency dental procedures was set up. Read the April 27 Health Alert.
On April 10, Governor Phil Scott extended his order of dental health care professionals practicing in Vermont to suspend all elective dental care until May 15, 2020. This order applies to both children and adult patients. Read Addendum 9 to the Executive Order for more information.
Health care professionals must continue to be available to their patients as needed for emergencies and urgent care.
Read the March 23 Health Alert as it pertains to emergency and elective dental care in light of COVID-19, the rationale for this action, including definitions of what constitutes a dental emergency and conditions requiring urgent care.
Find more information for health care professionals.

question: What is the Health Department doing?
answer:
The Vermont Department of Health is working closely with long-term care facilities and other group living facilities to prepare for COVID-19 cases and prevent outbreaks, by reviewing CDC guidance for infection control and supporting development of strategies and plans. If cases occur in these settings, the Vermont Department of Health helps the facility implement control measures and prevent additional cases.
The Department does contact tracing to investigate possible travel or exposure history and to identify anyone who had close contact with the person who has tested positive for COVID-19. Those individuals will be assessed for their exposure risk and provided with guidance for their health. Where appropriate, they will receive recommendations for self-isolation or other restrictions. Please note, the Health Department only uses a live person for contact tracing and never uses anything that sounds like a âroboâ (computer-generated voice) call.
Find up-to-date information on the Health Department's COVID-19 website.

question: Are bars and restaurants open?
answer:
On April 10, the Governor extended his order (effective Tuesday, March 17 at 2 p.m.) closing all bars and restaurants statewide until May 15.
Establishments can continue to offer food take out and delivery.
Find up-to-date guidance and mandatory health and safety requirements for bars, restaurants and food service from the Agency of Commerce and Community and Development (ACCD), which requires employees to wear non-medical cloth face masks or coverings (bandanna, scarf, or non-medical mask, etc.) over their nose and mouth when in the presence of others.
Find more health resources for businesses and read the Health & Safety Tips for Essential Businesses.
The ACCD wants to hear from all Vermont businesses impacted by the response to the COVID-19 virus. Please share your experiences on the ACCD Business Impact Form, which will help them assess the full impact as they work toward solutions.

question: Are property management and landscaping businesses allowed to operate?
answer:
Property management and landscaping businesses may conduct limited in-person operations. Find up-to-date guidance and mandatory health and safety requirements for property management and landscaping from the Agency of Commerce and Community and Development (ACCD), which requires employees to wear non-medical cloth face masks or coverings (bandanna, scarf, or non-medical mask, etc.) over their nose and mouth when in the presence of others.
Find more health resources for businesses and read the Health & Safety Tips for Essential Businesses.
The ACCD wants to hear from all Vermont businesses impacted by the response to the COVID-19 virus. Please share your experiences on the ACCD Business Impact Form, which will help them assess the full impact as they work toward solutions.

question: What do employers need to do to reopen their business?
answer: All businesses must follow mandatory health and safety requirements as they reopen. Find up-to-date, sector-specific guidance and mandatory health and safety requirements from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD).

question: What information is available for managers and owners of apartment complexes to help prevent the spread of COVID-19?
answer: For guidance on preventing the spread of COVID-19 for managers and owners of apartment complexes, visit healthvermont.gov/COVID19-groupliving. Find information for making a plan, preparing common spaces and communicating with residents or staff, in addition to outlining the role of the Health Department.

question: What should businesses and non-profits do?
answer:
Vermont is starting a phased approach to reopen the economy, balancing overall social and economic wellbeing with preventing a rise in COVID-19 that would set us back.
Find up-to-date, sector-specific guidance and mandatory health and safety requirements from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD). This includes requiring employees to wear non-medical cloth face masks or coverings (bandanna, scarf, or non-medical mask, etc.) over their nose and mouth when in the presence of others and other protective measures.
Businesses deemed âessentialâ may continue to operate under pre-existing guidance, with the addition of the mandatory health and safety requirements. Find more on new work safe additions to the Stay Home, Stay Safe Order.
Find more health resources for businesses and read the Health & Safety Tips for Essential Businesses.
The ACCD wants to hear from all Vermont businesses impacted by the response to the COVID-19 virus. Please share your experiences on the ACCD Business Impact Form, which will help them assess the full impact as they work toward solutions.

question: What should people in long-term care facilities or group homes do?
answer:
On April 24, the Health Department recommended that all health care personnel in long-term care facilities, correctional facilities, and other congregate settings where health care is provided wear face masks, regardless of the presence of COVID-19 in the facility.
As of March 13, no visitors are allowed in nursing homes, assisted-living facilities and state therapeutic care residences. Medically necessary personnel and visitors for residents receiving end-of-life care are allowed.
Senior Centers and Adult Day Programs have closed their programs in
compliance with the Governorâs State of Emergency in Response to
COVID-19. As of April 10, that executive order has been extended until
May 15. At which time the Governor, in consultation with the Vermont
Department of Health and the Department of Public Safety/Division of
Emergency Management shall assess the emergency and determine whether to
amend or extend the State of
Emergency.
Find guidance for long-term care and group living
settings.

question: What is considered an essential service or function?
answer:
Businesses and entities providing services or functions deemed critical to public health and safety, as well as economic and national security can remain open and do not need to suspend in-person operations. However, they must follow new mandatory health and safety requirements, such as wearing cloth face masks or coverings, social distancing, hygiene and cleaning requirements. Essential state and local government services and functions remain open. Find the list of essential services or functions.
For more information, read the Agency of Commerce and Community Developmentâs (ACCDâs) Stay Home, Stay Safe FAQs for Businesses and COVID-19 Recovery Resource Center for Businesses.

question: Where do the test samples get processed?
answer:
As of March 20, 2020, health care providers submit samples to the University of Vermont Medical Center Laboratory (UVMMC) for prioritization. Samples from higher risk populations will be tested at the Vermont Department of Health Laboratory. Lower priority tests are done at commercial labs.
The number of Vermonters who were tested for COVID-19 is updated daily on the Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard.

question: Is there universal (widespread) testing being done at group living facilities?
answer:
In Vermont, additional measures are being taken to slow the spread of COVID-19 in certain types of group living facilities. This includes nursing homes, corrections facilities, residential homes for people with disabilities, residential treatment centers, assisted living facilities, state psychiatric care facilities, and homeless shelters. In the event of a COVID-19 positive staff or resident, universal testing of all staff and residents is offered at these facilities. Staff and residents may decline testing, and facilities may decline universal testing.
Additionally, when a person tests positive at a skilled nursing facility, sequential testing is offered to those who tested negative during the universal testing.

question: Where can I get tested for COVID-19?
answer:
If you are having symptoms of COVID-19, call your health care provider for a referral. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected with a local community or hospital-connected clinic for a referral to a test site. If you are having a medical emergency, call 9-1-1 or go to the hospital.
Health care providers are encouraged to order a test for any child or adult who is showing symptoms of COVID-19, even if their symptoms are mild.
Find out what to do if you are
sick
from the CDC and what to do while youâre waiting for test
results.
Pop-up Testing Sites
Any Vermonter without symptoms can be tested at a pop-up testing site without a doctorâs referral. This includes people who work in Vermont, second homeowners, and college students. Registration for testing is required. For people who do not have internet access and want to register at a
pop-up site, they can call 2-1-1 for help with registration.
Register for a pop-up testing site.
The test is a nasopharyngeal swab, or NP swab, where a health care professional uses a swab to collect a sample from the back of the nose and throat. This test will tell you if you have a current infection. It is not a serology/antibody test, which means it will not tell you if you were infected in the past.
The following groups are encouraged to get tested at pop-up sites: health care workers, first responders (EMS, fire, and law enforcement), child care providers currently serving essential workers, and anyone currently under quarantine who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine. Find more details under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.

question: What do I do if I believe I had close contact with someone who has COVID-19?
answer:
If you have been in close contact with a person who tested positive for COVID-19, monitor yourself for symptoms. This includes checking your temperature every day, watching for symptoms and staying home.
If you develop symptoms of COVID-19 and are a close contact of someone who tested positive, you should:


Call your health care provider and


Call the Vermont Department of Health at 802-863-7240.


If you do not develop symptoms, you do not need to call the Health Department.
Read what to do if you're a close contact of someone with COVID-19.

question: What do I do if I'm a close contact of someone who is waiting for their test results?
answer:
People can be contagious for up to 48 hours before showing symptoms, so you should quarantine for 48 hours or until the test results come back.
If the test results come back positive (the person has COVID-19), then you should continue to quarantine for 14 days.
If the test results come back negative (the person does not have COVID-19), then you should start self-observation.
Read the What is isolation, quarantine and self-observation? chart for details.

question: What if Iâve had contact with someone who is under monitoring?
answer:
There is no identifiable increased risk to someone who has been in a home or in close contact with a person who is under monitoring and is NOT sick (experiencing symptoms).
People are thought to be most contagious when they are most symptomatic (the sickest). It might be possible to spread the virus before people show symptoms â there have been reports of this happening â but this is not thought to be the main way the virus spreads.

question: Should I wear a cloth face mask or covering when I go out in public?
answer:
As the state continues to reopen, it is more important than ever to make wearing cloth face masks or coverings a habit and to bring one with you whenever you leave home. Cloth face masks or coverings need to be worn in public settings when a physical distance of at least 6 feet is difficult to maintain. For example, visiting a grocery store or on a crowded sidewalk or bike path.
As part of Governor Scottâs Work Smart & Stay Safe - Restart VT: Phase 3, people are required to wear cloth face masks or coverings over their nose and mouth when using public transportationâincluding buses, trains and ride services, and in mass transportation stations or terminals, including airports. Additionally, businesses and non-profit and government organizations may require customers or clients to wear cloth face masks or coverings.
The advice to wear cloth face masks or coverings is based on data about how COVID-19 can spread before a person has any symptoms. Because people may have COVID-19 but no symptoms, wearing cloth face masks or coverings may help keep people from spreading the virus.
We all still need to stay at least 6 feet away from people, even when wearing cloth face masks or coverings, practice good hand hygiene and follow the stateâs Stay Home, Stay Safe guidance.
The cloth face mask or covering must be worn properly to be effective and avoid the spread of germs:


Wash your hands before putting it on.


Be sure your mouth and nose are covered.


Hook loops around your ears or tie it snugly.


Do not touch it or pull it down while in public.


Keep it on until you get home.


Remove it without touching your eyes, nose or mouth, then wash your hands immediately.


Wash it and make sure itâs completely dry before using again. Have a few on hand so you can rotate for washing.


Some people should never wear a cloth face mask or covering, including:


Children under the age of 2


Anyone who has trouble breathing, or is unconscious


Anyone who is unable to remove it without assistance


Medical-grade mask supplies are needed for our health care workers and first responders. Please use cloth face masks or coverings for your yourself and loved ones.
If you feel sick, stay home to rest and avoid going out into public places. If you are sick and plan to see a doctor, you should call the office before your visit. Your doctor can provide guidance on how to avoid spreading illness, such as what steps to take while traveling to their facility and upon arrival.
Learn more about using cloth face masks or coverings to help slow the spread of COVID-19.
Learn how to safely connect with friends and family.

question: Do homemade cloth face masks or coverings work?
answer:
As the state continues to reopen, it is more important than ever to make wearing cloth face masks or coverings a habit and to bring one with you whenever you leave home. Cloth face masks or coverings need to be worn in public settings when a physical distance of at least 6 feet is difficult to maintain. For example, visiting a grocery store or on a crowded sidewalk or bike path.
Wearing a homemade cloth face mask or covering can offer some protection to others. This is because people may be infected with COVID-19 and not show symptoms for up to two days (48 hours). The cloth face mask or covering can contain respiratory droplets and prevent them from spreading to others.
While health care workers may be able to use homemade cloth face masks or coverings as a last resort, medical-grade masks are considered personal protective equipment. These should be reserved for health care workers.
Learn more about using cloth face masks or coverings to help slow the spread of COVID-19.

question: How can I make my own homemade cloth face mask or covering?
answer:
Homemade cloth face masks or coverings can be made using simple materials found in most homes. For example, an old t-shirt or bandanna and rubber bands or hair ties. Your cloth face mask or covering should include multiple layers of fabric and allow you to be able to breathe easily. Watch a quick video by the CDC on how to make your own cloth face mask.
As the state continues to reopen, it is more important than ever to make wearing cloth face masks or coverings a habit and to bring one with you whenever you leave home. Cloth face masks or coverings need to be worn in public settings when a physical distance of at least 6 feet is difficult to maintain. For example, visiting a grocery store or on a crowded sidewalk or bike path.
Learn more about using cloth face masks or coverings to help slow the spread of COVID-19.

question: What does close contact mean?
answer:
Close contact means being within 6 feet, for a long time, of someone who has tested positive for COVID-19 during their infectious period, which starts two days (48 hours) before any symptoms began and continues until they are recovered. Close contact does not mean being more than 6 feet away in the same indoor environment for a long period of time, walking by, or briefly being in the same room with someone.
A âlong period of timeâ is hard to define because it depends on whether the person was sick at the time and what type of interaction you had with that person. These examples can help you determine whether you were a close contact or not.
Examples of close contacts:


You live in the same home.


You are intimate partners.


You rode in the same car while the person was infectious.


You had dinner together while the person was infectious.


Examples of not close contacts:


You were their cashier at the grocery store.


You are a pharmacist who gave the person medication.


You were in front of the person in line at the store.


You are a coworker who briefly walked by to ask a question.


A team at the Health Department works with people with COVID-19 to identify their close contacts. This is called contact tracing. The team assesses each close contact for their exposure risk and gives them health guidance and recommendations for self-isolation or other restrictions.
As the state reopens, Vermonters should consider keeping a contact journal â a list of other people who you have been in close contact with
each day. If you do get sick, this would make it easier to get in touch
with those people and so they can take proper precautions to prevent further spread of COVID-19.
The chart describing what is isolation, quarantine and self-observation has details about what you should do and not do, depending on your exposure risk.
Find out more about what to do if you are a close contact of someone who is diagnosed with COVID-19.

question: Where can I buy cloth face masks or coverings?
answer:
The Department of Public Safety has put together a list of businesses with available cloth face masks or coverings. Please check the list of where to buy cloth face coverings. Many Vermonters can also use homemade cloth face masks or coverings to offer some protection to others.
You can also reach out to your community. Check out places like Front Porch Forum to connect with other Vermonters making cloth face masks or coverings.

question: Can I use reusable grocery bags?
answer:
Yes, people can continue to use reusable grocery bags. However, some stores are choosing to no longer allow reusable bags and containers at this time. Check with your local store for their current policies.
Current evidence suggests that the COVID-19 virus may live for hours to days on surfaces made from a variety of materials. It may be possible that a person can get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or possibly their eyes, but this is not thought to be the main way the virus spreads.
It is important to remember to wash your hands before you eat and avoid touching your face. Washing or wiping down your reusable bags with a disinfectant continues to be a best practice for preventing bacterial illnesses, such as E.coli, from meat and unwashed fruits and vegetables.

question: Is it safe to go grocery shopping?
answer:
Currently there is no evidence to show that the COVID-19 virus is spread through food or food packaging. However, there is concern about being able to keep at least 6 feet away from other shoppers and to reduce your risk of getting sick while getting groceries.
The Vermont Retail & Grocers Association has a regularly updated list of what services Vermont retailers and grocers are offering during the COVID-19 pandemic. These services range from limited delivery, to curbside pickup and designated shopping hours for vulnerable populations.
Anyone who is sick or thinks they might be sick should stay home. Ask a family member, friend or neighbor to help you get your groceries, or see about having food delivered.
When you leave the store, you should wash your hands or use hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol. Read more about shopping for food during the COVID-19 pandemic guidance from the Food and Drug Administration.

question: How do I wash or sanitize my hands to keep from getting sick?
answer:
CDC recommends the following for hand hygiene: Household members should clean hands often, including immediately after removing gloves and after contact with someone who is ill, by washing hands with soap and water for 20 seconds. If soap and water are not available and hands are not visibly dirty, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol. However, if hands are visibly dirty, always wash hands with soap and water.
Hand Sanitizer Recipe (based on recipe from the World Health Organization):


1 cup (250 mL) isopropyl
alcohol (91%)


1 teaspoon (5 mL) glycerol
(or other moisturizer such as aloe vera gel, warm honey or olive oil)


2 Tablespoons (33 mL) water


Add the ingredients in the order listed above to a clean container, mixing with a spoon. If using honey, stir until the honey is completely dissolved. Keep this mixture out of the reach of children. The final concentration of isopropyl alcohol in this mixture is 75%, so keep it away from flames.

question: What types of disinfectants should I be using to clean?
answer:
Read the CDC's cleaning and disinfecting your home guidance.
Make sure you are using cleaning products and disinfectants safely. Follow these guidelines:


Follow the directions on the label


Donât mix chemicals


Wear protective gear (such as gloves)


Use them in a well-ventilated area


Store them out of reach of children


If you feel sick after using disinfectants, you can chat with the New England Poison Control Center on their website, call 1-800-222-1222 or text POISON to 85511.

question: How can I prepare at home?
answer:
Plan ways to care for those in your home who might be at greater risk for serious complications, like older adults (65 years and older) and people of any age who have underlying medical conditions. Make sure those who need regular medicine, medical supplies and equipment have what they need.


Choose a room in your home that can be used to separate sick household members from those who are healthy. Identify a separate bathroom for the sick person to use, if possible. Plan to clean these rooms, as needed, when someone is sick.


Make sure you have enough groceries and other supplies for 14 days in case you get sick and need to quarantine. Stock up on only what you will need for 14 days. Do not buy more than you will need so you can leave supplies for other people.


Get support from others. Talk with your neighbors about emergency planning. If your neighborhood has Front Porch Forum, consider joining to connect with neighbors, information and resources. Stay in touch by phone or email with family and friends, especially those who are 65 years and older, who have underlying medical conditions, or who live alone.


Take care of the emotional health of your household members. Outbreaks can be stressful for adults and children. Talk with your children about the outbreak, try to stay calm, and reassure them that they are safe.


Keep a daily list of other people you are in close contact with. As the state reopens, Vermonters should consider keeping a contact journal. If you do get sick, this would make it easier to get in touch with those people and so they can take proper precautions to prevent further spread of COVID-19.


Read Preventing COVID-19: Tips for Large Households or Extended Families Living in the Same Space.

question: Are there any recommendations for older adults (65 years and older) and people of any age with underlying medical conditions?
answer:
According to the CDC, some people might be at higher risk of getting very sick from COVID-19, including older adults (65 years and older) and people of any age who have serious underlying medical conditions like heart disease, diabetes, lung disease or moderate to severe asthma, severe obesity, chronic kidney disease undergoing dialysis, liver disease, or people who are immunocompromised including cancer treatment. People who live in a nursing home or long-term care facility are also at high risk of getting very sick from COVID-19.
In addition to the general COVID-19 prevention steps, older adults and people with underlying medical conditions should take extra precautions including:


Continue your medications and do not change your treatment plan without talking to your health care provider.


Stay home as much as possible, leaving only for essential
purposes, like going to the grocery store and pharmacy. Consider having
groceries or medications delivered.


Have at least a 2-week supply of prescription and non-prescription medications.


Talk to your health care provider about whether your vaccinations are up to date.


Do not delay getting emergency care for your underlying medical condition because of COVID-19.


Call your health care provider if you have any concerns about your underlying medical conditions or if you get sick and think that you may have COVID-19.


Read the CDCâs full guidance on people who are at higher risk for serious illness from COVID-19.

question: How can I safely run errands for essential purposes?
answer: The CDC has guidance on how to meet basic household needs, such as going grocery shopping, picking up medicine, picking up take-out, banking, getting gas, and going to doctor visits. Read the CDCâs Running Essential Errands guidance.

question: How can I help protect myself from getting the virus?
answer:
The best way to prevent yourself and others from getting sick with COVID-19 is to avoid being exposed to the virus. The virus is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person. Everyone should:


Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after being in a public place, before eating, and after blowing your nose, coughing, or sneezing.


If soap and water are not readily available, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol. Cover all surfaces of your hands and rub them together until they feel dry.


Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth.


Stay at least 6 feet away from people you donât live with.


Avoid close contact with people who are sick.


Wear a cloth face mask or covering in public settings when a physical distance of at least 6 feet is difficult to maintain. For example, at a grocery store or on a crowded sidewalk or bike path.


Stay home when you are sick.


Cover your coughs and sneezes with a tissue or the inside of your elbow. Throw used tissues in the trash. Then immediately wash your hands with soap and water or use an alcohol-based sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol.


Clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces daily.


Learn more about COVID-19 prevention and how to protect yourself and others.

question: How long can the virus live on surfaces?
answer:
Current evidence suggests that the COVID-19 virus may live for hours to days on surfaces made from a variety of materials, according to the CDC. It may be possible that a person can get COVID-19 by touching a surface or an object that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or possibly their eyes. However, this is not thought to be the main way the virus spreads. The virus is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person.
Cleaning and disinfecting frequently touched surfaces daily are the best ways to help stop the spread of the COVID-19 virus in households and community settings.
Read the CDC's cleaning and disinfection for households guidance for more information.

question: Can ticks or mosquitoes spread the COVID-19 virus?
answer:
At this time, the CDC has no data to suggest that the COVID-19 virus or other similar coronaviruses are spread by mosquitoes or ticks. The virus is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person.
Learn how to prevent mosquito bites and how to prevent tick bites.

question: Can I take ibuprofen for COVID-19 symptoms?
answer:
Some early news reports suggested that non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as ibuprofen, could worsen coronavirus disease. However, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has said it is not aware of any scientific evidence connecting the use of NSAIDs with worsening COVID-19 symptoms at this time. The FDA is investigating this issue further.
There are multiple medicines you can buy with or without a doctorâs prescription that are approved for pain relief and fever reduction. Please read warning labels on all medications before using them and consult with your health care provider about what is best for you.

question: What is the difference between COVID-19 and the flu?
answer:
COVID-19 is a new disease and we are still learning about how it makes people sick.
Cause
COVID-19: Caused by one virus, the novel 2019 coronavirus, now called severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2, or SARS-CoV-2.
Flu: Caused by any of several different types and strains of influenza viruses.
Transmission
While both the flu and COVID-19 may be transmitted in similar ways, there is also a possible difference: COVID-19 might be spread through the airborne route, meaning that tiny droplets remaining in the air could cause disease in others even after the ill person is no longer near.
Antiviral Medications
COVID-19: Antiviral medications are currently being tested to see if they can address symptoms.
Flu: Antiviral medications can address symptoms and sometimes shorten the duration of the illness.
Vaccine
COVID-19: No vaccine is available at this time, though it is in progress.
Flu: A vaccine is available and effective to prevent some of the most dangerous types or to reduce the severity of the flu.
Find out more about deaths and infections from Johns Hopkins Medicine.

question: Can people who recover from COVID-19 be infected again?
answer: The immune response to COVID-19 is not yet understood. Patients with another type of coronavirus, MERS-CoV (also known as MERS) are unlikely to be re-infected shortly after they recover, but it is not yet known whether this is true for people sick from COVID-19.

question: What should I do if I feel sick and think I may have COVID-19?
answer:
If you are having symptoms of COVID-19, call your health care provider to find out if you should be tested.
Follow these guidelines to help keep others from getting sick:
Isolate at home:


Donât leave home, except to get medical care. Call ahead before visiting a health care provider or emergency department. Wear a cloth face mask or covering if you need to leave home for medical care


Most people with mild illness can recover at home. While there is no specific treatment for COVID-19, you should get plenty of rest, drink plenty of fluids, and take fever-reducing medication if needed.


Stay in a specific room in your home and use a separate bathroom, as much as possible. Stay at least 6 feet away from others in your home at all times and wear a cloth face mask or covering if you are in the same room with them. Donât share household items.


Have someone else care for your pets. There have been a small number of pets, including cats and dogs, reported to be infected with the COVID-19 virus, mostly after close contact with people with COVID-19. If you must care for your pet, wear a cloth face mask or covering, and wash your hands before and after.


Daily cleaning and washing:


Clean and disinfect surfaces in your separate room and bathroom. Have someone else clean the other areas of your home.


Thoroughly wash household items, like utensils, after using.


Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. Use alcohol-based hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol if soap and water arenât available.


Find out what to do if you are diagnosed with COVID-19.
For more information, see CDC's guidance on what to do if you are sick.

question: I tested positive for COVID-19 but I never had symptoms. When can I stop home isolation?
answer:
If you didnât have symptoms when you were tested, you may stop home isolation when:

at least 10 days have passed since the date of your first positive COVID-19 test and
you still have not had any symptoms

After stopping home isolation, continue to stay 6 feet away from others and wear a cloth face mask or covering whenever other people are present.

question: What should I do if Iâm being monitored by the Health Department and then become sick?
answer:
If you have developed symptoms of COVID-19 AND


Have returned from China or Iran, or are a close contact of a person who tested positive for COVID-19, you should:

Call your health care provider and
Call the Vermont Department of Health at 802-863-7240.



If you are being monitored because you have returned from an affected area other than China or Iran, or by cruise ship, you should call your health care provider if you become sick. It is not necessary to call the Health Department to report symptoms.

question: Does sunlight kill the COVID-19 virus?
answer: Currently, the World Health Organization says there is no evidence that sunlight kills the COVID-19 virus.

question: What is isolation, quarantine and self-observation?
answer:
Isolation is for people who are sick with COVID-19.


Quarantine is for people with no symptoms and who were in close contact with someone sick with COVID-19 or are returning to Vermont from out of state for anything other than an essential purpose.


Self-observation is for other Vermonters who donât have symptoms of COVID-19.


For more information, see the What is isolation, quarantine and self-observation? chart.

question: What is monitoring?
answer:
Monitoring means someone who has returned from an affected area or cruise ship and does not have symptoms of COVID-19. They are advised by the Health Department to check their temperature every day, watch for symptoms, and quarantine for 14 days. Information that may identify someone under monitoring is not available to the public.
Anyone currently under quarantine who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine has the option to be tested at a pop-up testing site without a doctorâs referral. Registration is required. Find more details under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.
The Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard includes the number of people being monitored and who have completed monitoring and is updated every day.

question: When can I stop self-isolating (home isolation)?
answer:
People with COVID-19 who have stayed home (home isolated) can stop home isolation under the following conditions:
If you will not have a test to determine if you are still contagious, you can leave home after these three things have happened:


you have had no fever for at least 72 hours (that is three full days of no fever without the use medicine that reduces fevers) AND


other symptoms have improved (for example, when your cough or shortness of breath have improved) AND


at least 10 days have passed since your symptoms first appeared


If you will be tested to determine if you are still contagious, you can leave home after these three things have happened:


you no longer have a fever (without the use medicine that reduces fevers) AND


other symptoms have improved (for example, when your cough or shortness of breath have improved) AND


you received two negative tests in a row, 24 hours apart.


Your doctor will follow CDC guidelines. In all cases, follow the guidance of your health care provider and the Health Department. The decision to stop home isolation should be made in consultation with your health care provider and the Health Department.

question: How does COVID-19 spread?
answer:
The virus is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person.


Between people who are in close contact with one another (within about 6 feet).


Through respiratory droplets produced when an infected person coughs, sneezes or talks.


These droplets can land in the mouths or noses of people who are nearby or possibly be inhaled into the lungs.


Some recent studies have suggested that COVID-19 may be spread by people who are not showing symptoms.


It may be possible that a person can get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or possibly their eyes, but this is not thought to be the main way the virus spreads.
Learn from the CDC how to help prevent spread of the virus and how to protect yourself and others from getting sick.

question: Can I get the virus from food?
answer:
Unlike foodborne gastrointestinal (GI) viruses that often make people sick from contaminated food, COVID-19 is a virus that causes respiratory illness. The COVID-19 virus is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person. Currently, there is no evidence to show that COVID-19 is spread through food or food packaging.
It is important to always follow general food safety guidelines:


Wash your hands with soap and water for 20 seconds before preparing or eating food.


Throughout the day, wash your hands after blowing your nose, coughing or sneezing, or going to the bathroom.


It may be possible that a person can get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object, like a package or container, that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or possibly their eyes, but this is not thought to be the main way the virus spreads.
Find shopping for food during the COVID-19 pandemic guidance from the FDA and tips on how to handle and prepare food safely from the CDC.
Learn from the CDC how to help prevent spread of the virus and how to protect yourself and others from getting sick.

question: Can I get the virus from touching my mail or paper products?
answer:
According to the U.S. Postal Service, CDC, World Health Organization, and the U.S. Surgeon General, there is currently no evidence that COVID-19 is being spread through the mail or paper products.
The COVID-19 virus is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person. It may be possible that a person can get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or possibly their eyes, but this is not thought to be the main way the virus spreads.
Learn from the CDC how to help prevent spread of the virus and how to protect yourself and others from getting sick.

question: Can the COVID-19 virus spread through pools and hot tubs?
answer:
There is no evidence that COVID-19 can be spread to humans through the use of pools and hot tubs. Proper operation, maintenance, and disinfection (for example, with chlorine and bromine) of pools and hot tubs should remove or inactivate the virus that causes COVID-19.
Find more information from the CDC's Water and COVID-19 FAQs.

question: I am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?
answer:
Anyone currently under quarantine who is not a health care worker or a correctional worker, and who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine has the option to be tested at a pop-up testing site without a doctorâs referral. Registration is required.
This includes:


people returning to Vermont (for example, those who spend winter outside of Vermont, second homeowners and college students)


visitors coming into Vermont


close contacts of people who have tested positive


For anyone coming into Vermont, Day 0 is the day you arrive in Vermont.
Health care workers and correctional workers must complete the full 14-day quarantine.
You can end your quarantine period only if:


You have not had symptoms during your quarantine period.


You are tested on Day 7 or later.


You remain in quarantine until the result comes back.


You receive a negative test result and are still not having symptoms.


However, you must continue to monitor yourself for symptoms for the full 14 days and isolate at home immediately if symptoms develop.

question: How can I keep from getting sick if I live with or care for someone who is sick with COVID-19?
answer: The CDC has advice to protect yourself or others if you are caring for someone with COVID-19. You can learn what to do when someone has symptoms of COVID-19, when someone has been diagnosed with COVID-19, or when someone who has tested positive but is not showing symptoms. Read Caring for Someone Sick at Home and Guidance for Large or Extended Families Living in the Same Household from the CDC.

question: What does social distancing mean?
answer:
Social distancing means maintaining a physical distance (approximately 6 feet or 2 meters) from others you do not live with. This includes when you're inside a store or outside for exercise.
The COVID-19 virus spreads easily from person-to-person. It travels through the air when a sick person coughs, sneezes or talks. One way to contain the spread of COVID-19 is to stop people from sharing it. Without a vaccine or treatment, we can help contain the virus by:


Staying at home to protect others if you are sick.


Staying home is still the best way to lower our risk of COVID-19, but small groups of 10 or fewer people are now allowed if health and safety precautions are followed. Learn how to safely connect with friends and family.


Continuing to go outside, take walks, do essential errands while maintaining a physical distance from others and practicing proper hygiene. Remember that ticks are active this time of year. Find out how to Be Tick Smart and prevent tick bites.


Wearing a cloth face mask or covering in public settings when a physical distance of at least 6 feet is difficult to maintain, especially at the grocery store, pharmacy, doctorâs office, hospital or other essential business or office, and on a crowded sidewalk or bike path.


Washing your hands (adults and children) any time you go inside, before you eat, and before you spend time with people who are more vulnerable to the effects of COVID-19.

question: Iâm young. Can I continue to socialize?
answer:
Whatever your age, staying home is still the best way to lower our risk of COVID-19, but many of us are eager to take small steps to safely see our friends and family again. Small groups of 10 or fewer people are now allowed if health and safety precautions are followed. Learn how to safely connect with friends and family.
While older adults (65 years and older) and people of any age with underlying medical conditions are at greatest risk, young people are not immune to getting sick. Even people who show only mild symptoms may pass the virus to others â particularly in the early course of the infection, before they even realize they are sick. Taking health and safety precautions protects everyone and helps slow the spread of this virus.

question: How can community helpers and volunteers keep from getting sick with COVID-19?
answer:
Making sure neighbors have what they need is crucial, but we need to make sure helpers and volunteers are still taking precautions to protect our most vulnerable Vermonters. Common sense practices can go a long way while Vermonters take care of each other.
The Vermont Department of Health recommends any volunteers bringing items to those who need to stay home:


Keep a distance of 6 feet away.


Avoid entering the personâs home.


Wear a cloth face mask or covering.


Wash your hands regularly.


Avoid touching your face and cover your cough or sneeze with a tissue, then throw the tissue in the trash.


Stop doing community support work immediately if you feel sick or find out you have had contact with someone who is sick.


Keep a list of anyone you come into close contact with in case contact tracing is required.


Wear clean gloves when handling items that may be given to people with a weaker immune system, and when you are close to someone who may be sick.

question: I have recovered from COVID-19. Can I donate my blood plasma to help other people suffering from COVID-19?
answer:
People who have fully recovered from COVID-19 have antibodies in their blood plasma. This is the bodyâs immune response to the virus. Currently, plasma donations are only being done experimentally. It has not yet been confirmed by the scientific community. However, it could prove to be important in the future to treating serious cases of illness from COVID-19.
The Red Cross is looking for people who are fully recovered from COVID-19 and may be able to donate plasma. If you are fully recovered from a COVID-19 diagnosis that was confirmed by a lab test and would like to donate your plasma, fill out the form on the Red Cross website.

question: Iâm a health professional and would like to volunteer. How do I get a temporary license?
answer:
Health care professionals can quickly become temporarily licensed to provide care during the COVID-19 public health emergency. This includes people who were previously licensed, even if they are retired from practice and do not hold an active license in any state.
The new emergency measures grant a temporary license for health professionals who:

Are licensed and in good standing in other states
Were licensed in Vermont, but whose licenses lapsed in recent years

There are no fees of any kind to obtain a temporary emergency license.
The process for applying will depend on the applicantâs status. Some just need to submit information about who they are and where they will be practicing. Others will be required to apply for the license using a streamlined process.
To apply for a license or get more information about the process contact the licensing authority for your profession:

Board of Medical Practice (medical doctors, physician assistants, and podiatrists) or 802-657-4223.
Office of Professional Regulation (other health care professions â including nurses and osteopathic physicians) or 802-828-1505.

question: Is volunteering allowed under the Stay Home, Stay Safe Order?
answer:
Yes, as long as it is with an agency that is essential for public health and safety or is included in the Governor's new safe work additions. The best way to volunteer is virtually. If you would like to help by packing donated food or something out in the community, you can only if:


The non-profit is eligible to be open


A safe workspace can be provided


There is enough social distancing between volunteers (at least 6 feet)


You wear a cloth face mask or covering

question: Can I be tested for COVID-19?
answer:
If you are having symptoms of COVID-19, call your health care provider to be tested. Health care providers are encouraged to order a test for any child or adult who is showing symptoms of COVID-19, even if their symptoms are mild.
Anyone currently under quarantine who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine has the option to be tested at a pop-up testing site without a doctorâs referral. Registration is required. Find more details under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.
There is no cost to individuals for the COVID-19 test.
The number of Vermonters who were tested for COVID-19 is updated daily on the Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard.
As of April 29, the State began expanding testing. We know that with increased testing we are likely to see a rise in positive cases, and we are prepared to handle such a scenario. A new Testing and Tracing Task Force has been created to guide and oversee this process.

question: Does the Health Department have enough resources for testing?
answer: Testing capacity in Vermont and in the U.S. has improved since mid-March. We have worked continuously to grow our stock of in-state supplies and to build relationships with private labs to help speed up processing of tests. Testing is done seven days a week with typically 1- to 3-day turnaround times. In addition to the Health Departmentâs lab, the University of Vermont Medical Centerâs lab and commercial labs are doing COVID-19 testing.

question: Can I donate unused personal protective equipment (PPE)?
answer: Yes, you can donate unused, unopened N95, medical or surgical masks by simply dropping them off at your nearest Vermont State Police Barracks.

question: How accurate is the test for COVID-19?
answer: The test used by the Vermont Department of Health Laboratory has a sensitivity rate of 95%, which means the test correctly gives a positive result 95% of the time. Sensitivity rates may be different at other labs.

question: How long is the turnaround for testing?
answer:
Test results will be available typically within 1 â 3 days. You will get your test results from your health care provider. However, if you received a positive result, the Health Department will also reach out to talk to you about public health recommendations and ask questions about people you were in contact with. It is possible that the Health Department may contact you before your health care provider does.
Find out what to do while you're waiting for test results. Contact your health care provider with any questions.
The number of Vermonters who were tested for COVID-19 is updated daily on the Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard.

question: How much does the test cost?
answer: There is no cost to individuals for the COVID-19 test.

question: Is Vermont conducting tests for COVID-19?
answer:
Yes, the Vermont Department of Health Laboratory, University of Vermont Medical Center and commercial labs are running tests for COVID-19.
The number of Vermonters who were tested for COVID-19 is updated daily on the Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard.

question: My health care provider is out-of-state. Can I be tested in Vermont?
answer: Yes, out-of-state health care providers can refer their patients for COVID-19 testing in Vermont. Ask your health care provider for a referral.

question: Should I be tested for COVID-19?
answer:
If you are having symptoms of COVID-19, call your health care provider to be tested. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected with a local community or hospital-connected clinic for referral to a test site.
Health care providers are encouraged to order a test for any child or adult who is showing symptoms of COVID-19, even if their symptoms are mild.

question: Who is getting tested for COVID-19 in Vermont?
answer:
If you are having symptoms of COVID-19, call your health care provider to be tested. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected with a local community or hospital-connected clinic for referral to a test site.
Health care providers are encouraged to order a test for any child or adult who is showing symptoms of COVID-19, even if their symptoms are mild.
We ramping up our testing capabilities to conduct 1,000 tests a day â or 7,000 tests a week. We know that with increased testing we are likely to see a rise in positive cases, and we are prepared to handle such a scenario. A new Testing and Tracing Task Force has been created to guide and oversee this process.
Testing is currently available for:


Any adult or child with symptoms of COVID-19 â even if their symptoms are mild â who has been referred for testing by their doctor.


Long-term care facilities and other group living settings:

All residents and staff in group living settings, where there has been a single positive test. This includes nursing homes, assisted living facilities, prisons, and certain high-density residential buildings.
If there is a person who has tested positive with COVID-19 at a skilled nursing facility, they can be retested at 3 days, 7 days, 10 days and 14 days after the initial test. This is to help prevent community-wide outbreaks.
*For all sites, regardless of whether a person has tested positive, testing is offered at intake, discharge, and for certain residents who require regular care outside of the facility.



Staff at correctional facilities


Any Vermonter without symptoms can be tested at a pop-up site without a doctorâs referral, but registration for testing is required. Regular test collection locations still require a doctorâs referral.

The following groups are encouraged to get tested at these sites: health care workers, first responders (EMS, fire, and law enforcement), child care providers currently serving essential workers, and anyone currently under quarantine who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine. Find more details under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.

question: How does a health care professional collect samples for COVID-19 testing?
answer:
While wearing personal protective equipment like gloves and a mask, the health care professional collects samples (specimens) from the patient in one of three ways:


The patient coughs up saliva and mucus into a collection cup or dry container.


The health care professional collects a nasal, or nasopharyngeal (NP) swab. This is when a dry swab is inserted through one nostril and is rubbed against the back of the nose and throat.


The health care professional collects an oral swab. This is when a dry swab is inserted into the patientâs mouth and is rubbed against the tonsil and throat area.

question: Can I volunteer to help with the Stateâs response to COVID-19?
answer:
Yes, people with medical and health care skills and those with other needed skills can sign up for volunteer assistance to support the stateâs response to COVID-19. We currently have a contact tracing team in place, but these are other ways you can help.
People with medical or other health care backgrounds are needed to support the health care providers responding to the COVID-19 pandemic. Vermontâs Medical Reserve Corps units are community-based groups of volunteers who supplement local emergency and public health resources with their existing skills.
Sign up with the Vermont Medical Reserve Corps if you:


Are a licensed and certified health care professional


Have health, mental health, or other types of clinical or professional experience


Have health care administrative experience, such as with medical data entry or language translators


Have worked with displaced individuals, such as homeless shelter programs


Vermont has eased licensing requirements for the purposes of aiding this emergency response. Physicians, physician assistants and podiatrists can learn more on the Board of Medical Practice website. Other medical professionals, including nurses and osteopathic physicians, can learn more on the Office of Professional Regulation's website.
Other individuals who have needed skills (for example, drivers, food service, construction, IT, security, skilled trades, etc.), can sign up at vermont.gov/volunteer and indicate their expertise and availability.
Vermonters can also contribute to blood banks, food banks, and other emergency supply efforts. The American Red Cross of Northern New England faces a severe blood shortage and many local food banks and other community organizations are in need of support and donations of supplies.
Give blood: Learn how to safely donate blood with the American Red Cross.
Support your local Foodbank by donating online or you can text GIVEHEALTH to 85511. The Vermont Foodbank can help if you need it.
You can also help your neighbors â older adults (65 years and older) and people of any age who have underlying medical conditions should stay home as much as possible. Go shopping for a neighbor or someone else in need, keep an older neighbor company by phone or at a safe distance. When volunteering please follow the guidelines on being a good neighbor.

question: Is it safe to go to the hospital?
answer:
If you are having symptoms of a more serious medical condition, such as heart attack or stroke, it is important to get medical care right away. Call 9-1-1, go to the emergency room, or call your doctor if your symptoms are not life-threatening.
It is safe to seek care at Vermont hospitals. They have measures in place to protect patients in the hospital from getting COVID-19. This includes separating patients with COVID-19 from other patients. There is a greater risk to staying at home if you're experiencing symptoms of a serious medical condition than going to the hospital.
As of May 4, health care providers may also begin to do some clinic visits, diagnostic imaging, and outpatient surgeries and procedures again â as long as they have a minimal impact on inpatient hospital bed capacity and personal protective equipment (PPE). This does not include elective surgeries that require staying at the hospital, which are not permitted at this time. Read the Governorâs press release for details.

question: How can I take care of myself, my family, or friends with the stress from COVID-19?
answer:
Feeling anxious, confused, overwhelmed or powerless is common during an infectious disease outbreak. Taking care of yourself, your friends, and your family can help you cope with stress. Helping others cope with their stress can also make your community stronger.


Take breaks from watching, reading, or listening to news stories, including social media. Hearing about the pandemic repeatedly can be upsetting.


Take care of your body. Take deep breaths, stretch, or meditate. Try to eat healthy, well-balanced meals, exercise regularly, get plenty of sleep, and avoid alcohol and drugs.


Make time to unwind. Try to do some other activities you enjoy.


Connect with others. Talk with people you trust about your concerns and how you are feeling.


Find more information on coping with COVID-19 stress, including resources for local help, self-care, suicide prevention, and domestic violence.
Find more tips for coping with stress from the CDC, including how to help children cope with stress.
Need support right now?


Call your local mental health crisis line


Text VT to 741741


Call 2-1-1 or 1-866-652-4636


Contact the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline or call 1-800-273-8255


For multilingual support, call 800-985-5990 or text TalkWithUs to 66746

question: Is there a medicine I can take to prevent or treat COVID-19?
answer:
As reports appear in the news of certain drugs being potentially used for treatment or prevention of COVID-19, the Vermont Department of Health strongly urges caution.
Though the anti-malarial drugs chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine, among others, have been widely discussed as potential treatments, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has said there are no data currently available from randomized clinical trials that would inform how these drugs could be used to treat COVID-19.
In fact, there are significant potential risks to taking such drugs, including death.
Health officials remind Vermonters that most people who get COVID-19 can manage their symptoms at home with rest, drinking fluids and taking fever-reducing medication. Talk to your health care provider before taking any substance alleged to prevent or treat COVID-19.
Providers should only prescribe these drugs for individuals with diagnosed conditions, and not for prevention, to help maintain the supply for Vermonters who need them.

question: Is there a vaccine for COVID-19? When will a vaccine be available?
answer: There is no vaccine for COVID-19, but research and work are underway to develop one.

question: What does the Stay Home, Stay Safe Order mean for Vermonters?
answer:
Vermonters may now leave home to get fresh air, begin limited social interactions and gatherings of 10 or fewer preferably in outdoor settings, provided that we follow health and safety precautions to keep disease from spreading. This means:


Keeping a physical distance of at least 6 feet away from others (except for those you live with).


Washing or sanitizing your hands often.


Wearing a cloth face mask or covering in public settings when a physical distance of at least 6 feet is difficult to maintain (for example, at a grocery store or on a crowded sidewalk or bike path).


Staying home and away from others if you are sick with COVID-19, have recently been exposed to someone who has COVID-19, or just donât feel well.


Learn how to safely connect with friends and family. These recommended practices will help you weigh the risk and plan accordingly.
Read the latest updates to the Stay Home, Stay Safe Order.
The Agency of Commerce and Community Development has resources for individuals and sector-specific guidance for details on which businesses are open.

question: Are mass gatherings allowed?
answer:
As of May 6, Vermonters are now allowed to gather in small groups of 10 or fewer people as long as health and safety precautions are followed. Members of one household may now choose to socialize â and allow children to play â with members of another trusted household that is also taking health and safety precautions. Learn how to safely connect with friends and family.
Gatherings of more than 10 people are still prohibited. This includes weddings, graduation ceremonies, and other social gatherings.
If leaving the home, Vermonters should adhere to social distancing policies, including remaining 6 feet from others (except for those with whom they share a home), wearing a cloth face mask or covering, and thoroughly and regularly washing hands.
Find up-to-date information on the Health Department's COVID-19 website.

question: Are sports and outdoor activities allowed?
answer:
We encourage Vermonters to go outside and enjoy the fresh air. Exercise, outdoor activities, and taking in Vermontâs natural beauty is important for our mind and bodies.
Businesses, non-profit and government entities that support or offer outdoor recreation and outdoor fitness activities with low or no direct physical contact can open on May 7. These include, but are not limited to, state and municipal parks, recreation associations, trail networks, golf courses, big game check stations and guided expeditions.
Campgrounds, marinas and beaches are not permitted to open at this time. Find up-to-date information on outdoor recreation and campgrounds from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development.
Contact sports and games should not be played at this time.
We can safely continue to enjoy outdoor activities with these measures:


Stay close to home. Find local outdoor recreation areas and consider day trips that are close to home. Only drive with members of your household.


Take health and safety precautions. Keep the virus from spreading by staying at least 6 feet apart from other people outside of your household, washing or sanitizing your hands, and staying home when you are sick.


Bring a cloth face mask with you. Put a cloth face mask or covering on if you encounter other people and stop to chat or if you are on a crowded trail or bike path.


Be cautious and choose low-risk activities to avoid injury. This will help lower the burden on our hospitals and health care system.


Respect signs for closed areas, trails and land. Check Trail Finder to find out if your trail is currently open before you visit. Call ahead or check websites for information on outdoor recreation facilities before you head out.


Choose no-contact sports: For example, biking, hiking, horseback riding, tennis, boating and golfing. Outdoor basketball courts may be open to shoot hoops, but signage should be posted prohibiting contact games. Do not share sports equipment with people outside of your household.


Check for ticks and wear an EPA-registered tick repellent. When youâre out walking or spending time in your backyard, remember that ticks are active this time of year. Find out how to Be Tick Smart and prevent tick bites.


Find out more about outdoor recreation and COVID-19 from the Vermont Department of Forests, Parks and Recreation and the Vermont Fish and Wildlife Department.
Learn how to safely connect with friends and family.

question: Can I buy or sign a long-term lease (more than 30 days) for a new apartment or house?
answer:
Long-term rental leases are allowed. Moving and moving services are also allowed, so long as social distancing guidelines are followed. More housing information is available at the Agency of Commerce and Community Development's (ACCDâs) COVID-19 Resource Recovery Center.
Real estate services, including real estate firms, brokerages, attorneys or individuals, must conduct as much work as possible remotely to minimize in-person contact. Real estate and related services (such as title searches, appraisals, and home inspections) are allowed to begin limited operations again. Find details and up-to-date information on real estate from the ACCD.

question: Can I get together with friends and family?
answer:
On May 6, the Governor announced Play Smart and Play Safe: Restart VT Phase 5, which gives Vermonters a chance to reunite and enjoy each otherâs company. This allows Vermonters to leave home to get fresh air and exercise and to resume limited social interactions and gatherings of 10 or fewer people, preferably in outdoor settings, as long as health and safety precautions are taken. Learn how to safely connect with friends and family.
Members of one household may choose to socialize â and allow children to play â with members of another trusted household, such as family, neighbors or friends. A trusted household is one that has taken seriously the importance of social distancing and proper hygiene in their day-to-day lives. By carefully limiting these closer social interactions at this time it will be easier to identify who else may have been exposed and need to self-isolate in case someone becomes sick.
To keep COVID-19 from spreading, we must continue to:


Stay home and away from others if you are sick with COVID-19, have recently been exposed to someone who has COVID-19, or just donât feel well.


Keep a 6-foot distance from others when you meet people outside of your household.


Wash your hands frequently (hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol is acceptable when soap and water are not available).


Cough and sneeze into your elbow (even if you are wearing a cloth face mask or covering).


Wear a cloth face mask or covering over your nose and mouth.


Older adults (age 65 and over), and people with underlying medical conditions, like heart and lung disease or diabetes, are more likely to develop severe illness. They should continue to stay home, and family and friends should do everything they can to help keep them safe.

question: Can we still have our wedding ceremony?
answer:
At this time, marriage ceremonies are discouraged, and officiants must ask to postpone services. But if a ceremony is held, it must be in accordance with the governorâs orders. This includes limiting gatherings to fewer than 10 people in the same space at the same time.
Visitors from other states and countries are asked not to come to Vermont at this time. If they do come to Vermont, they must stay at home (quarantine) 14 days before participating in any activities out of their home or lodging.
Anyone currently under quarantine who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine has the option to be tested at a pop-up testing site without a doctorâs referral. Registration is required. Find more details under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.
Learn more about quarantine on the what is isolation, quarantine and self-observation chart.
However, there are some exceptions, and this guidance may change. Find up-to-date information on marriage ceremonies from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development.

question: Does the Stay Home, Stay Safe Order mean I can be arrested or will need special papers if I leave my home?
answer:
Enforcement of the Governor's Stay Home, Stay Safe Order will be mainly be done through education and voluntary compliance.


The Order does not close roads and does not establish roadblocks or checkpoints.


Motor vehicle and pedestrian traffic will continue as Vermonters do outdoor activities that are allowed and travel to and from businesses (including grocery stores and pharmacies) and other entities that are allowed to operate under the Order.


There will not be motor vehicle stops or people detained for questioning about their travel, but law enforcement officers may be reminding people of the Order if they see groups gathering or businesses operating in violation of the Order.


Read the latest updates to the Stay Home, Stay Safe Executive Order.

question: How can I report a person or business who is violating the Stay Home, Stay Safe Order?
answer:
The Department of Public Safety and the Vermont State Police recommended to Vermont municipal leaders and law-enforcement executives that enforcement of the Governorâs Stay Home, Stay Safe Order be handled mainly through education and voluntary compliance.


For concerns about businesses or lodging facilities that are violating the Stay Home, Stay Safe Order, use the Department of Public Safetyâs non-compliance complaint form to gather more information.

question: When will COVID-19 infections peak? When will the Stay Home, Stay Safe Order end?
answer:
Most recent modeling data suggests Vermont has reached its peak in the number of new cases of COVID-19, hospital capacity, and the number people who are currently infected with COVID-19.
However, it is important to remember there are still many people who are currently infected and therefore, are contagious and could spread it to others.
Vermont is looking at four key measures to inform steps to reopen:


Ongoing reduction in cases for at least 14 days


A health care system that is safely able to treat all patients without exceeding its capacity or using crisis standards of care


The ability to test all people with symptoms


Widespread active monitoring of people who have tested positive for COVID-19 and tracing their close contacts


At this time, Vermont has seen a reduction in cases for at least 14 days. This is hopeful news. To continue on this path, it is critical that Vermonters continue making their day-to-day sacrifices to help save lives. Social distancing (staying at least 6 feet from each other) and wearing cloth face masks or coverings are here to stay for a while, even as we being to reopen, until we have effective antiviral medicines or a vaccine.

Though it is likely that both the virus and immune system contribute to this process, it can be difficult to determine which mechanism causes the most damage. To establish infection, a virus must enter a host cell. Once inside, it hijacks the cell’s machinery to replicate, eventually killing the cell and releasing more virus. This process not only damages host tissues, but also potently activates the immune system. The immune system in turn unleashes powerful weapons to control the infection. However, if not carefully regulated, the immune response itself can cause collateral damage to host tissues and exacerbate disease severity. More research on the host and viral factors that contribute to severe COVID-19 disease and death could provide important clues for clinicians and researchers in the search for new treatments.

question: What is cryptic transmission, and what is its significance in the COVID-19 outbreak?
answer: Cryptic transmission is the term that is used when there is no direct contact between person 1 shedding the virus and person 2 contracting it. Cryptic transmission is the term that is used when there is no direct contact between person 1 shedding the virus and person 2 contracting it. It is an important indicator of community prevalence of a virus. There is essentially enough circulating virus in a community to transmit the same strain of the virus between individuals who are not directly linked. In the case of the COVID-19 outbreak, this term came into the lexicon after University of Washington researchers sequenced the COVID-19 genome from Snohomish County, Washington, which showed a direct genetic link from the first 2 cases in Washington though they had no known contact. This indicated there was significant community spread, and likely evidence the virus had been circulating for weeks by that point. As I noted on Twitter, the key takeaway is this is going to be a critical path for viral transmission given the potential infectivity prior to the manifestation of symptoms—and what will ultimately make it so hard to control the spread of the virus.

question: Why are wild animals believed to be the source of this outbreak?
answer:
About 60% of newly emerged and re-emerging pathogens share a common origin: the bodies of animals. Genetic and epidemiological evidence suggest that the novel coronavirus, like SARS, may have emerged from a so-called “wet market,” where wild species that would rarely encounter each other in nature are crammed together, allowing microbes to spread between species and into humans. China claimed to have cracked down on these markets after the SARS outbreak, but when I visited a few years later, it wasn’t hard to find one. 
But such markets are only part of the problem. The loss of wildlife habitat around the world more generally is forcing wild species to cram into closer proximity to human settlements. Bats, for example, have been fingered as the source of Ebola, SARS, and a host of other pathogens. When we cut down the forests where they live, they come roost in our backyards and farms instead. It’s this kind of novel, intimate contact that provides opportunities for the microbes that live in their bodies to spread into ours. question: Why will it likely take longer to develop a vaccine than a drug for COVID-19?
answer: The development of vaccines and drugs for COVID-19 share common goals: to ensure safety and efficacy. These are often assessed through a series of studies, sometimes beginning with animal experiments, progressing through human phase 1, 2 and 3 clinical trials with increasing numbers of participants. However, it often takes much longer to develop and rigorously assess a vaccine. First, vaccines are usually targeted to healthy people, in contrast to drugs administered to people with disease. Larger and longer studies are often needed to ensure the safety of vaccines. Second, the outcomes of interest often take much longer to be measured. Vaccine efficacy and immunogenicity can take many months to measure accurately, whereas whether or not a treated patient improves can take days. And some vaccines require multiple doses spread out over months whereas drug treatment regimens typically are days to weeks. Once developed, it can also take longer to manufacture and deploy vaccines.
